required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Local Anesthetic Wound Infiltration on Postoperative Pain Following Cesarean Delivery
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of Local Anesthetic Wound Infiltration on Postoperative Pain Following Cesarean Delivery

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if the infusion of the local anesthetic ropivacaine (a numbing medicine) and the non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug ketorolac (a pain killer similar to ibuprofen) through a catheter placed along the cesarean delivery incision, will reduce the pain experienced after cesarean section and need for narcotic pain medicine.

primary_outcome.measure: Pain Score on Movement (Sitting in Bed From a Supine Position)
primary_outcome.description: Score reported on a scale of 0-10, with 0 being none and 10 being the worst imaginable

Score reported on a scale of 0-10, with 0 being none and 10 being the worst imaginable

arm_group.description: Subjects will receive 440 mg ropivacaine and 30 mg ketorolac. Infusion of study medication will start after the skin is sutured and will continue for 48 hours after cesarean delivery.
Subjects will receive saline placebo. Infusion of study medication will start after the skin is sutured and will continue for 48 hours after cesarean delivery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- American Society of Anesthesiology (ASA) class 1,2, and 3
- English speaking women at a gestational age > 37 weeks
- scheduled for cesarean delivery under spinal or combined spinal epidural anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- BMI > 50 kg/m2
- history of intravenous drug or opioid abuse
- previous history of chronic pain syndrome
- history of opioid use in the past week
- allergy or contraindication to any of the study medications
- non-English speaking

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: This study recruited participants from the Duke Labor and Delivery population, as they presented for scheduled Cesarean Delivery.

group.description: Subjects will receive saline placebo. Infusion of study medication will start after the skin is sutured and will continue for 48 hours after cesarean delivery. Placebo

reported_events.time_frame: From Anesthesia start to 48 hours postoperatively.
reported_events.desc: Patients were asked at 2 hours, 24 hours and 48 hours to rate any symptoms on a scale of 0-10, with 0 being none at all and 10 being the worst imaginable symptom

group.description: Subjects will receive saline placebo. Infusion of study medication will start after the skin is sutured and will continue for 48 hours after cesarean delivery. Placebo

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
